content.description: This is one sandy spire with groovy hoodoos nearby.  Not recommended for rock climbing, consider photography instead.  First pitch is a sandy thrash up a gutter, second is legit climbing on choss.
content.protection: There are a couple fixed pins, one at the top of P1, another I pulled on to get past the crux (hence A0).   See topo for more nympho.
content.location: Not in Glen Canyon Rec area but close enough.  Near the Pariah ranger station on 89.  Looks nice from the road.  Stay there and enjoy it, just don't do this spire.

content.description: This is mostly a chimney with a few crack moves for good measure.  The rock starts off with some integrity but degrades the higher you climb.  Still a great view atop this small perch.  The last move to said perch is the crux.
content.protection:
You will need one each of the following:  BD .3, .4, #1, and a #2.  You will also need 3 quick draws and two shoulder length runners.

There are four hand drilled bolts (put up ground up) on the line that followed the best rock.  Some may need extending.  The anchor on top (three bolts) is the best we could do.  A baby angle and more tat would improve the situation.
content.location:
A mostly flat and beautiful 45 minute hike. Start in the Buckskin Wash parking lot/trail head, where a restroom is provided. Leave a note on your wind shield that you are not going in to the pay areas OR pay and avoid any issues. Hike down Buckskin Wash for about 15 min.s until you see a prominent side canon on you left. Cut up and north here. On two occasions you will have to forage around a steep spillage but always follow this drainage. Eventually you will reach the band of white cliffs and Paria Pillar. See the map. I "think" I am correct here.

The line is in the space formed between the pillar and the main wall or on Paria Pillar"s north wall.  The south wall or exposed side, has a crack that will also go free (see photos below).

When the side canyon levels out and runs up into the white cliffs, cut left and north west to the obvious detached pillar.

content.description: We were looking for the ultimate offwidth/chimney, but climbed this instead.  Loose rock, crux is at the roof and topping out without sending a sandstone salvo down on your belayer. Dirty, wet, and loose.
content.protection: Big pro (see topo).  Rap anchors a bit upstream on the rim.  Hand-drilled in '97 so...
content.location:
This route is on the left-hand wall as you walk down

Buckskin Gulch

. There is a fee required to access this wilderness area (pay at the trailhead), and you gotta pack out your doo-doo. May require several swims, a frigid prospect in winter.
